pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:2.1: The nuns’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:3.1: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:5.1: 69. The training rule on following preceptors
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:6.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:6.2: At that time nuns who had received the full ordination did not follow their preceptor for two years.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:6.4: and they did not know what was allowable and what was not.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:7.1: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:7.2: “How can those nuns receive the full ordination and then not follow their preceptor for two years?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:7.3: “Is it true, monks, that nuns do this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:7.6: How can nuns receive the full ordination and then not follow their preceptor for two years?
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:7.7: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:7.8: And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:8.1: ‘If a nun does not follow the preceptor who gave her the full ordination for two years, she commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:9.4: … The nun who has been given the full ordination by both complete Orders through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:10.1: Who gave her the full ordination:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:10.2: who gave her the full ordination.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:10.4: the preceptor is what is meant.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:10.8: does not herself attend on her.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:10.9: If she thinks, “I will not follow her for two years,” then by the mere fact of giving up the duty, she commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:11.2: if the preceptor is ignorant or shameless;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:11.6: if she is the first offender.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69:12.1: The ninth training rule is finished.
